awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  The function of vocal learning ability in African elephants
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. A key attribute of human language is vocal learning, or the ability to learn to produce new sounds, which is only found in a limited number of other species. Understanding the few cases in which vocal learning has evolved could therefore shed light on the evolutionary origins of language. One possible function of vocal learning is that it allows animals to make their calls sound more like those of their social group members, which serves as a sign of group membership. Another possible function is to allow animals to learn unique sounds to address specific individuals, similar to the way in which humans use names. The Fellow will test both of these hypotheses in African elephants, in which vocal learning is known to occur but is poorly understood. Understanding why elephants have developed vocal learning could provide insight into the conditions that led to the evolution of this unusual but important ability in human ancestors. This project will also provide mentorship and outreach programs for students from underrepresented groups, and will contribute to the Fellow's professional development.

To test the hypothesis that elephants learn vocal signatures of group identity, the Fellow will determine if the calls of group members are more similar than the calls of members of different groups independent of relatedness. To determine if elephants recognize close and distant associates at the individual or group level, the Fellow will play back two overlapping calls from the same caller, which should only violate the subjects' expectations if they recognize the caller at the individual level. To test the hypothesis that elephants vocally label conspecifics, the Fellow will determine whether the acoustic structure of a contact call varies according to the intended recipient of the call, and whether individuals are more likely to respond to playbacks of a call that was originally directed towards them, independent of the identity of the caller. The Fellow will hone quantitative skills in acoustic analysis and statistics, and will gain career-enhancing experience in conservation biology through collaboration with other members of the sponsoring lab. The Fellow will also mentor undergraduates conducting acoustic ecology research, and teach workshops at local Hispanic-serving schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall aim of this project was to investigate why elephants have evolved the ability to learn to modify their vocalizations and imitate new sounds. This ability, called vocal production learning, is essential to human language, but is rare in other mammals. Thus, understanding the function of vocal production learning in the few nonhuman mammals that possess this ability could help us understand the evolution of this important ability in our own species. Elephants are capable of mimicking novel sounds in captivity, but it was unknown how they make use of this ability in the wild.

We investigated two non-mutually exclusive possibilities for how wild elephants might use vocal production learning:

1)      Elephants address one another with individually specific name-like calls (which would require vocal production learning to learn the “names” for other individuals).

2)      Elephants use vocal production learning to make their calls more like the calls of those around them, resulting in elephants from the same social group or population sounding more similar to one another than to elephants from a different social group or population.

We recorded calls from wild elephants in Kenya, noting when possible the identity of the caller and the identity of the recipient (the individual that the caller was addressing). To address the question of whether elephants have name-like calls, we attempted to train a machine learning model to guess the identity of the intended recipient of a call based on the call’s acoustic structure. If the model could learn to do this, that would suggest that elephant calls contain information identifying the intended recipient (i.e., a name). The model correctly predicted the recipients of the calls significantly better than if it had been guessing randomly, supporting our hypothesis that calls contain name-like features. We then played back calls to the elephants and found that they reacted more strongly to calls that were originally addressed to them relative to calls from the same caller that were originally addressed to someone else. This suggests that elephants can determine just by hearing a call if it was intended for them or for someone else, which further supports the hypothesis that the calls contain name-like features. Prior to this study, name-like calls had only been documented in bottlenose dolphins and some parrots. The finding that elephants also address one another with name-like calls provides an opportunity to investigate the commonalities between these species that may have led to the evolution of names. These results are currently under review for publication in a peer-reviewed journal. The PI (Michael Pardo) also presented these results at five academic conferences between 2021 and 2023. This study was also featured in a documentary produced by Scripps News called “How scientists are using AI tech to communicate with animals” https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQFPL9JLQEY.

We also conducted a separate analysis to determine if elephant calls differ between two populations in Kenya or among different social groups in the same population. We found that calls differed substantially between the two populations, and that they differed more subtly among social groups in the same population. While it is possible that these differences could be the result of factors other than vocal production learning, we believe that vocal production learning is the most likely cause. This suggests another possible function of vocal production learning in elephants; members of the same social group might learn a similar vocal “signature” to make it easier for elephants to recognize which group another individual belongs to. The finding that elephants from different populations in Kenya sound different has implications for conservation because wildlife managers sometimes translocate elephants between populations. The fact that elephants in different populations communicate differently could complicate the social integration of elephants who are moved to a new population. This study is also under review for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.

The PI of this project also engaged in outreach and education efforts to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in biology. He designed and taught two workshops on acoustic analysis, including one for students at University of Northern Colorado, a Hispanic-serving institution. He also taught a workshop on Microsoft Excel for conservation professionals in Kenya. He helped create and teach an undergraduate course titled “Mapping culture and conservation” with Dr. Sara Bombaci at CSU, which explores issues related to DEI and conservation. This course will continue to be offered at CSU. Finally, the PI mentored an undergraduate student (Piper Dumont) who completed an independent project on the social context of elephant greeting calls, which has been submitted for publication.
